description.narrative:
New/additional funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 UNICEF has applied to Sida for funding of 15 million SEK to carry out the implementation of UNICEF's activities within the thematic area "Child Protection" in BiH as part of the UNICEF Strategic Plan 2018-2021 and as outlined in the UNICEF Country Programme Document 2015-2020 in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
The objectives of the Programme are: -- By 2019, an increased number of boys and girls use a continuum of child protection services aimed at preventing and adequately responding to violence, neglect and abuse and family separation, and equitable access to justice is strengthened for all children. -- Strengthened children and their families’ capacity to demand child protection services -- Service providers better equipped to deliver child protection services -- Children at- risk, child victims and witnesses of crime, children as parties in civil and administrative proceedings and children in conflict with the law better served and protected

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 UNICEF har ansökt hos Sida för 15 miljoner SEK i finansiering för att utföra implementeringen av UNICEF:s aktiviteter inom det tematiska området ”Child Protection” i BiH som en del av UNICEF:s strategiska plan 2018-2021 och som skissades i UNICEF Country Program Document 2015-2020 i Bosnien och Hercegovina.
Målen för programmet är: - Till 2019, ett ökat antal flickor och pojkar använder ett kontinuum av tjänster inom barnskydd riktade att förhindra och ge adekvat respons på våld, försummande, missförhållanden och familjeseparation, och att rättvis tillgång till rättvisa för alla barn stärks. - Stärka barnen och deras familjers kapacitet att kräva barnskyddstjänster. - Att service givare är bättre utrustad att leverera barnskyddstjänstera. - Att barn i riskzonen, barn som är offer och vittnen till brott, barn som är del av civilrättsliga och administrativa framfaranden och barn i konflikt med lagen är bättre omhändertagna och skyddade.

Support to UNICEF core/thematic programme in BIH has the overall objective (Outcome 2 of Country programme) that child protection systems are strengthened to prevent and respond to cases of violence, abuse, exploitation, and neglect of children, including institutionalization, and specifically to the following outputs and results: OUTPUT 1: Strengthened children and their families capacity to demand child protection services OUTPUT 2: Service providers better equipped to deliver child protection services OUTPUT 3. Children at risk, child victims and witnesses of crime, children as parties in civil and administrative proceedings and children in conflict with the law better served and protected

tag.narrative: 16.2 - Eliminera övergrepp, utnyttjande, människohandel och alla former av våld eller tortyr mot barn.
16.2 - End abuse, exploitation, trafficking and all forms of violence against and torture of children.

description.narrative: The reporting has been delivered on time and is according to the requirements set out in the thematic agreement. Key results achieved in 2020: -At least 160,000 children and 250,000 caregivers benefitted indirectly, while about 24,800 children and 7,000 caregivers benefitted directly from UNICEF-supported child protection programmes, including 7,362 children identified at risk of harm and/or offending, 1,618 children in contact with the law (365 victims, 337 witnesses and 910 alleged offenders), and about 3,500 children on the move of whom 1,900 unaccompanied children (UAC). -Based on the assessment of the implementation of the Republika Srpska (RS) Law on Protection and Treatment of Children and Juveniles in Criminal Proceedings, finalised in 2018, amendments to the legislation were adopted by the RS Parliament in 2020, expected to significantly improve implementation of diversion measures, protection of victims and witness and child-friendly interviewing. -UNICEF conducted rapid assessments of the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on social protection in Tuzla and Middle Bosnia Cantons, with the specific findings used for strategic planning in the social and child protection sector; -UNICEF enhanced the provision of community-based mental health and psychosocial support (MHPSS) for children and caregivers, including capacity building of more than 600 professionals in community-based MHPSS during the pandemic, reaching directly some 14,000 children and 2,800 caregivers; -UNICEF produced an assessment of the social service workforce (SSW) in child protection, providing recommendations on how to further enhance regulatory and institutional frameworks, planning, developing and supporting the SSW, -UNICEF ensured child protection support such as legal guardianship, case management protection standards to 3,500 children on the move, including 1,900 unaccompanied children, and to the extent possible adequate reception capacities for those children. UNICEF also operated five child-friendly spaces and distributed winter clothes and shoes to some 1,000 children -In response to the COVID-19 pandemic, IT Girls transferred its Postani IT Girl training programme to the online space and organised 13 #ITGirlsGoOline webinars, reaching around 35,000 girls and women through social media channels. More than 400 girls and young women benefited directly by participating in one of the IT Girls events, trainings or activities. Other highlights worth pointing out for 2020 are: UNICEF in partnership with IFS Emmaus established the Safer Internet Centre (SIC) in BiH, consisting of an Awareness Center, Helpline, Hotline (member of international network INHOPE) and Youth Panel, as well as the new, innovative and improved web platform (www.sigurnodijete.ba) were significantly promoted in 2020, including additional activities to raise awareness of increased risks to (online) child sexual exploitation and abuse. A total of 16,319 new users, and over 81,825 visits were registered. In partnership with the Roma NGO Romalen, UNICEF enhanced the well being and protection of Roma girls and boys, with a focus on addressing child marriage, violence, human trafficking, child labour and discrimination. In 2020, UNICEF supported NGO Kali Sara – Roma Information Centre to prepare a case study on the enrollment of Roma children in the obligatory preschool programme. In July 2020 UNICEF for the first time launched the virtual ‘e-UPSHIFT’, a youth social innovation and social entrepreneurship programme, designed to build skills and opportunities for young people who are disadvantaged, due to (for example) poverty, gender, disability or ethnicity. The e-UPSHIFT with online engagement of trainers, mentors and 106 participating adolescents proved to be a significant success. Child protection professionals in BiH were equipped with the knowledge and skills on how to maintain and adapt critical child protection services, in particular community-based mental health and psychosocial support (MHPSS), in the context of COVID-19. More than 650 professionals benefited from training, and more than 60 institutions, including centres for social welfare (CSW), received personal protective equipment (PPE) and IT equipment. More than 14,000 children and 2,800 caregivers benefited directly and more than 250,000 adults and 100,000 children were reached indirectly with various actions. Improving child protection services and protection standards for children on the move remained a significant part of the interventions in 2020. In partnership with CSWs in Una-Sana and Sarajevo Cantons, Church World Service, LAN, Médecins du Monde, Save the Children, and World Vision, UNICEF operated Child-Friendly Spaces, deployed additional legal/special guardians to CSWs to help them manage the additional caseload, operated designated zones for unaccompanied children with 24/7 child protection teams in five reception centres. Four selected local communities - Zvornik, Prijedor, Kakanj and Kalesija - were supported to develop evidence-based local innovative solutions to respond to the COVID-19 pandemic and mitigate its effects on the most vulnerable families with children with disabilities. New services were provided for 85 children with disabilities and 77 parents/family members. In three Municipalities (Trebinje, Pale and Jajce) MoUs were signed with the Mayors to establish an integrated social protection and inclusion model, forming also multi-sectoral Commissions and Referral Teams. Trebinje Municipality was provided with a small grant to initiate the establishment of East Herzegovina Family Counselling Services, which will benefit vulnerable children and families, not only in case of disability but also in case of issues like violence, neglect or abuse. In close collaboration with Ministries of Education and Pedagogical Institutes, more than 150,000 children from over 400 primary and secondary schools benefited from school-based secondary prevention programmes, aimed at enhancing the well being and protection of children and adolescents through early identification and support from risk factors. The roll-out of the programme was initiated in Canton 10 and Una-Sana Canton, thus covering now all primary and secondary schools in Republika Srpska and the majority of primary schools in Canton 10, Sarajevo, Tuzla and Una-Sana. More than 7,000 children identified as at-risk received direct support through group and individual psychosocial support. The financial report for 2020 thematic budget execution is showing quite a large percentage of subgranting and overall low operating and general costs (less than 15%) which is assessed to be good. The IT Girls report was also submitted together with the thematic report for 2020. The IT girls component of the thematic support to UNICEF Child protection faced several challenges due to the pandemic. The training had to be moved to the online space. Campaign and webinars with 13 ICT companies were all implemented online. The number of visited schools was much lower (due to the pandemic). Only two schools were visited in 2020. The communication with the Ministry of Education in RS was maintained but all activities postponed until 2021. The online trainings was delivered in 12 towns spread out in BiH benefitting about 20 girls from a application pool of more than 70. Apart from a focus on involvement with IT companies, exploring the value of cooperation with those companies in BiH for the benefit of new job opportunities esp for women, the UNICEF project staff initatied a dialogue on what ICT sector role is for the whole concept of women econmic empowerment (WEP). The conclusion of several panel discussion with company representatives was that the ICT sector plays a key role in this regard. A selection was made by UNICEF of 5 comapnies for further work on WEP. Each company had to develop tools and actions plan for WEP during the year. Regular compaigns now recognized under the brand IT Girls continued in 2020 (International Women's Day, Women in Science and Technology Day, Arduino Day, etc) Regular activities continued with IT Girls mentorship activities (IT girls super network) which involved 23 women new participants and 28 Super IT Girls. Outreach through Facebook continued, and is reaching a record number of audience. Future strategizing took place jointly by the 3 UN agencies (UNDP, UNICEF and UN Women) for a new programme 2021-2025 for which fundraising is planned.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
